cookingMethod: Use a non-stick pan and spread a thin layer of dosa batter. Use only 1 tsp (5ml) of oil for greasing the pan.
healthTips: Dosa is naturally low in oil. Use a good non-stick pan to reduce oil usage further. Serve with sambar and coconut chutney for a balanced meal.

cookingMethod: Steam the idli batter in idli molds for 10-12 minutes. No oil required.
healthTips: Idli is a perfect zero-oil breakfast option. Rich in protein and easily digestible. Pair with sambar or chutney.

cookingMethod: Pressure cook dal. For tadka, heat 2 tsp (10ml) of ghee or oil, add cumin seeds, onions, and tomatoes. Pour over cooked dal.
healthTips: Use ghee instead of oil for better taste with the same quantity. Dal is protein-rich and the tadka needs minimal oil.

cookingMethod: Use 1 tbsp (15ml) oil to sauté onions, add ginger-garlic paste, tomatoes, and spices. Add vegetables and cook with little water.
healthTips: Steam or microwave vegetables first to reduce cooking time and oil absorption. Use a pressure cooker to minimize oil usage.

cookingMethod: Knead dough, roll into circles, and cook on a hot tawa. Apply minimal ghee (1 tsp/5ml) after cooking if desired.
healthTips: Chapati requires no oil during cooking. Apply ghee sparingly only for taste. Use whole wheat flour for added fiber.

cookingMethod: Blanch spinach and blend. Use 1 tbsp (15ml) oil to sauté onions, add tomatoes and spices. Mix in spinach puree and paneer cubes.
healthTips: Bake or air-fry paneer instead of deep frying. Use low-fat paneer to reduce overall fat content.

cookingMethod: Heat 2 tsp (10ml) ghee, add cumin seeds. Add washed rice, dal, vegetables, and pressure cook with water and spices.
healthTips: Khichdi is a comfort food that needs minimal oil. Rich in protein and easy to digest. Perfect for a light, healthy meal.

cookingMethod: Dry roast rava. Heat 2 tsp (10ml) oil, add mustard seeds, curry leaves, vegetables. Add water and roasted rava, cook until done.
healthTips: Upma is naturally low in oil. Add more vegetables to increase nutrition and reduce the proportion of semolina.

cookingMethod: Rinse poha and drain. Heat 2 tsp (10ml) oil, add mustard seeds, curry leaves, onions, potato. Mix in poha and spices.
healthTips: Poha is light and requires minimal oil. Add peanuts for protein and crunch. A perfect low-oil breakfast option.

cookingMethod: Pressure cook chickpeas with tea bag. Heat 1 tbsp (15ml) oil, sauté onions, add tomatoes, spices, and cooked chickpeas.
healthTips: Chickpeas are protein-rich and filling. Minimize oil by using a good non-stick pan for sautéing. Serve with brown rice or whole wheat kulcha.

cookingMethod: Cook dal and vegetables separately. For tadka, use 1.5 tsp (8ml) oil with mustard seeds, curry leaves. Mix everything with tamarind water and sambar powder.
healthTips: Sambar is packed with vegetables and protein from dal. The minimal oil in tadka provides flavor without excess calories.

cookingMethod: Steam potatoes and cauliflower lightly. Use 2.5 tsp (12ml) oil to sauté spices, add tomatoes, then mix in vegetables. Cook covered.
healthTips: Pre-steaming vegetables reduces cooking time and oil absorption. This dry curry needs minimal oil for maximum flavor.

cookingMethod: Cut okra and dry roast in pan. Use 2.5 tsp (12ml) oil to sauté onions, add tomatoes, spices, then mix in roasted okra.
healthTips: Dry roasting okra first eliminates the need for excess oil. Okra is rich in fiber and low in calories.

cookingMethod: Pressure cook rajma. Use 1 tbsp (15ml) oil to sauté onions, add ginger-garlic, tomatoes, and spices. Mix in cooked rajma.
healthTips: Kidney beans are an excellent protein source. The gravy needs minimal oil - use a non-stick pan for best results.

cookingMethod: Marinate paneer in spiced yogurt. Skewer with vegetables and grill/bake. Brush with 1.5 tsp (8ml) oil while cooking.
healthTips: Grilling or air-frying paneer tikka uses 80% less oil than traditional frying. High protein, low calorie appetizer.

cookingMethod: Grind soaked dal into batter. Spread on non-stick pan like pancake. Use 1 tsp (6ml) oil to cook each chilla until crisp.
healthTips: Moong dal chilla is a protein-packed breakfast. Use non-stick pan to minimize oil. Great for weight management.

cookingMethod: Partially cook rice. Sauté vegetables in 4 tsp (20ml) oil with spices. Layer rice and vegetables, cook dum style.
healthTips: Traditional biryani uses 3x more oil. This version maintains flavor with reduced fat. Load up on vegetables for nutrition.

cookingMethod: Roll stuffed paratha and cook on tawa. Use 1 tbsp (15ml) total ghee/oil for cooking 4-5 parathas (3ml each).
healthTips: Use whole wheat flour and minimal ghee. Stuff with vegetables for added nutrition. Pair with yogurt instead of butter.

cookingMethod: Steam gram flour batter. For tempering, use 1.5 tsp (8ml) oil with mustard seeds and curry leaves. Pour over dhokla.
healthTips: Dhokla is steamed, making it naturally low in oil. High in protein from gram flour. Perfect guilt-free snack.

cookingMethod: Partially cook rice. Sauté meat/vegetables in 4 tsp (20ml) oil with spices and yogurt. Layer with rice, cook dum style.
healthTips: Traditional biryani uses 60-80ml oil. This version uses 75% less while maintaining authentic taste. Choose lean protein options.
